Award.AwardTitle: Connections between redox chemistry and catalysis in multiheme peroxidases
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Sean Elliott of Boston University to study the protein dynamics and regulatory mechanisms of bacterial enzymes that detoxify hydrogen peroxide. A multi-disciplinary approach making use of protein electrochemistry, biochemistry and crystallography will be used to examine the molecular determinants that govern how a redox enzyme turns on or shuts down reactivity through pairing redox- and spin state- changes of heme cofactors to conformational changes in protein structure. Such studies can provide a molecular level understanding of redox-based mechanisms of the regulation of catalysis.

Enzymes are masters of transforming one molecule into another. In this way, bacterial enzymes called cytochrome c peroxidases (bCCPs) detoxify the reactive molecule hydrogen peroxide and transform it into harmless water. Enzymes such as bCCP often also master their own regulation, where they are turned either on or off. Understanding how enzymes regulate their own activity is a critical aspect of understanding how they can act as catalysts. Here, a wide range of biochemical, structural, spectroscopic, and electrochemical approaches will be brought to bear to understand the reactivity of "activatable" bCCP and elucidate the principles of what turns on (and off) their activity. The graduate and undergraduate students involved in these efforts will receive a multi-disciplinary training. This project will be integrated with continued mentoring efforts as students and the PI will develop and participate as leaders in an ongoing series of workshops in bioinorganic chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Bacterial cytochrome c peroxidases are enzymes that are often found in bacteria. Canonical members of this superfamily of enzymes are responsible for the detoxification of hydrogen peroxide which can be produced accidentally by their own biochemical machinery, or through the action of a mammalian immune system. However, other members of the superfamily are responsible for using hydrogen peroxide as a chemical oxidant, and they use that oxidizing power to transform other proteins, such as the precursor of methylamine dehydrogenase, taking an inactive protein precursor and generating a cross-linked, oxidized active site.  The primary focus of this project has been to understand how nature has created different enzymes that look so similar to one another and yet do different things, testing several hypotheses about what elements of bacterial cytochrome c peroxidase function can be attributed to specific functions.

In this project, we have made a series of variants of bacterial cytochrome c peroxidases from different sources. All members of the family contain two different heme cofactors that contain iron, one of these structures acts as the site where hydrogen peroxide binds and is transformed, and the other serves as a conduit or relay for the passage of electrons into the active site. This laboratory has shown that the nature of the amino acids at various sequence positions is essential for turning on or turning off the ability of the active site to work efficiently. We have employed x-ray crystallography to understand the structures of these variants and to pair their structural features with the chemical reactions that they will do. The PI and the graduate students that have been working on this project have made over 20 presentations about this work, at scientific meetings and universities.

Broader Impacts: Four graduate students and one undergraduate student have received training in protein biochemistry, molecular biology, electrochemistry, and the biophysical and structural methods in our studies of the bacterial cytochrome c peroxidase superfamily. These students have also received additional professional development in the form of training in teaching, scientific writing and oral communication, in order to enhance their skills as communicators and advocates for science. Two of the graduate students completed their masters, and one currently works in scientific publishing and the other in the biotech industry. One graduate student completed her Ph.D. and is continuing in science as a post-doctoral scholar, and the last is continuing her Ph.D. work currently. The undergraduate supported through this effort is also working in the biotech/pharma industry. Thus, significant human resource development was supported through this grant. Finally, these students all made contributions to ongoing efforts in the training of graduate students through the Penn State Bioinorganic Chemistry Workshop, where they and the PI have developed modules for training students in the cutting-edge techniques of protein electrochemistry, in order to disseminate our efforts and enhance the research skills of the next generation of scientists.
